title: 105_hr846
content: Section 1 introduces a new constructive sales treatment for appreciated financial positions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If there is a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position, the taxpayer must recognize gain as if the position were sold for its fair market value on the date of the sale. Any gain will be included in the taxable year of the sale. Adjustments will be made for subsequent gains or losses, and the holding period will be determined as if the position was acquired on the date of the constructive sale. The term 'appreciated financial position' refers to any position with potential gain upon sale, including interests in stock, debt instruments, or partnership interests. A taxpayer is considered to have made a constructive sale if they engage in activities like short selling or entering into offsetting contracts with substantially identical property. The term 'constructive sale' includes engaging in transactions that involve delivering, acquiring, or entering into contracts for substantially identical property, or transactions with similar effects. Transactions marked to market are exempt from being considered constructive sales. The term 'constructive sale' excludes sales of nonpublicly traded property within 1 year of contract entry and transactions closed by year end, disregarding certain appreciated financial positions. The term 'constructive sale' excludes certain transactions closed before the end of the taxable year, with specific conditions regarding timing and related persons as defined in sections 267 or 707(b). For tax purposes, certain transactions are excluded from being considered a 'constructive sale' if they meet specific conditions regarding timing and related persons as defined in sections 267 or 707(b). Additionally, positions in interest rates are treated as substantially identical to debt instruments for the purpose of this section. The term 'forward contract' includes fully or partially prepaid contracts, and an 'offsetting notional principal contract' involves paying the investment yield on a property in exchange for reimbursement for any decline in its value. For tax purposes, a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position triggers special rules for subsequent sales or dispositions, treating the taxpayer as entering into the transaction immediately after the sale. Certain trust instruments actively traded are treated as stock. Regulations will be prescribed as necessary to carry out the purposes of this section. Securities traders may elect mark to market. Securities traders may elect mark to market accounting method for dealers in securities without the consent of the Secretary, applying to the current and subsequent taxable years unless revoked. The table of sections for part IV of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by adding a new item without the consent of the Secretary. Sec. 1259 outlines the constructive sales treatment for appreciated financial positions. The effective date for these amendments applies to constructive sales after the date of enactment of the Act, and also to sales after January 12, 1996, but only if the taxpayer still owns the appreciated financial position and the transaction remains open with respect to the taxpayer or a related person. The new provision under section 1259 of the Internal Revenue Code applies to constructive sales occurring 30 days after the enactment of the Act. For decedents dying after the Act's enactment, if a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position occurred before the date of enactment and remains open with respect to the decedent or related person, gain recognition rules apply. The new provision under section 1259 of the Internal Revenue Code treats certain positions as property constituting rights to receive income in respect of a decedent. Securities traders can elect to be treated as dealers for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires taxpayers to adjust their accounting method over a 5-year period starting from the first taxable year after the enactment of the Act. Section 351 of the Code is amended to include all stock and securities held by a company in determining if it is an investment company, regardless of marketability. This amendment applies to transfers after the enactment date in taxable years ending after that date.
